page_analysis.text_content:
Step 2: Determine which perimeter segments abut the house walls. These are closed segments, or sides.

In Fig 5 sides A, B, & C abut the house walls.
These are considered to be closed segments.

Step 3: Determine the status (open/closed) of the remaining segments based on the design. If at least 50% of the facade area is
open, then the segment or side is considered open.

For purposes of assessing the openess of the facade:
• The height of the segment facades is measured from the top of the porch floor to the the point where the
segment facade intersects with the top of the roof material.
• The widths of the segment facades are measured from the same plane. Allowances may be made for
structural supports that are not excessive.

Intersection
facade & top
of roof material

visual_elements.description: An overhead view diagram of a structure with three segments labeled A, B, and C. Segment A is 3' long, segment B is 8' long, and segment C is 10' long. Segment C also shows a door opening. These segments are shown abutting house walls.

A series of four cross-section diagrams (D, E, F, G) illustrating different facade types and their 'open' or 'closed' status. Each diagram shows a segment with a base, vertical supports, and a roof structure. A dashed line indicates the 'Porch flr' (porch floor) and another dashed line with text 'Intersection facade & top of roof material' indicates the height measurement. The height is labeled 'Height = 8'' in diagram E. The widths of the segments are indicated below each diagram.

subheadings: For purposes of assessing the openess of the facade:

additional_notes: Page number '9' is present at the bottom right corner.
The text '8'' and '10'' in the top right diagram are slightly rotated to align with the segments.
The text 'Height = 8''' in diagram E is vertically oriented.
The text '(because of decorative glass wall)' is a parenthetical explanation for why segment E is 'Closed'.
